author: PGAHAN
pre_context: This text signifies that it discusses values greater than those previously calculated. For example, the WHO calculated a reproduction rate of 1.4 to 2.5. Li and associates (Li et al., 2020) reported a marginally higher figure, 2.2 (95% confidence interval, CI, 1.4 to 3.9), while various other mathematical models, both peer-reviewed and released as pre-prints, have shown that the reproduction rate ranges from 1.3 to 4.7. Among the published studies, two specifically addressed the underestimation of coronavirus cases: the research by Zhao's team (Zhao et al., 2020) and the study by Read and colleagues (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020). In particular, Zhao and his team (Zhao et al., 2020) quantitatively analyzed the underreporting of coronavirus cases by using an exponential growth Poisson process model. They estimated that there were 469 underreported cases of the virus (95% CI 403 to 540). From this data, the basic reproduction number was calculated to be 2.56 (95% CI 2.49 to 2.63). An earlier draft of this study, which was released on the bioRxiv pre-print server, had estimated the reproduction number to range from 3.30 (95% CI 2.73 to 3.96) to 5.47 (95% CI 4.16 to 7.10). It was also determined that the basic reproduction number could increase two-fold with every fold increase in reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an ascertainment rate of 5.0% (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Chengdu, China there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The
post_context: (95% CI 2.39e4.13). Regarding the impact on public health, to effectively curb the outbreak, it's necessary to interrupt at least 58% of the disease transmissions. Additionally, three models that include data on international travel have been proposed: those by Imai and team (Imai et al., 2020), Kucharski and colleagues (Kucharski et al., 2020), and Wu and associates (Wu, Leung, & Leung, 2020). Specifically, the study by Imai and colleagues (Imai et al., 2020) suggests a reproduction number of 2.6, with an uncertainty range between 1.5 and 3.5. The reproduction number was shown to fluctuate within 1.7 to 2.6 and then to 1.9 to 4.2 across various scenarios and levels of zoonotic exposure. Similarly, based on different generation time estimates, the reproduction number ranged from 1.3 to 2.7 and then from 1.7 to 4.3. According to Fig. 2, predictions and the impact of control strategies on infection assume that the parameters determined from data fitting between January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 (and therefore the interventions) stay the same. (AeB) illustrate the effects of reducing the minimal contact rate after January 29th, 2020; (CeD) depict the results of either reducing or increasing the size of the population susceptible to infection from January 29th, 2020 onwards.

pre_context: Figure 3 presents the best match of the model with the data on cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to February 1st, 2020, showing projected infected individuals (A), those quarantined (B), and the total confirmed cases to date (C). The infectiousness level caused the reproduction number to fluctuate between 1.6 and 2.9. It is presumed that the novel virus would lead to a higher number of mild-to-moderate cases compared to the SARS virus, with a reproduction number estimated at 2.0 (with an uncertainty range of 1.4 to 2.3). The study also indicates that public health measures that block more than 60% of transmission are essential for the effective control and containment of the coronavirus outbreak. Drawing upon the research by Imai and colleagues (Imai et al., 2020) and using a SIR model for analysis, Yu (Yu, 2020) calculated a basic reproduction number of 3.5, asserting that the quarantine rate for the infectious population needs to exceed 90% for successful outbreak management. Moreover, Kucharski and his team (Kucharski et al., 2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model that adapts the Euler-Maruyama algorithm for a 6-hour step and models transmission rate through geometric Brownian motion. The team estimated the time-varying reproduction number via the sequential Monte-Carlo method, tackling data unreliability by analyzing multiple datasets and employing the Poisson probability for accurate, real-time estimations. Transmission was modeled as a random process, fluctuating and varying over the time. Similar to the model of Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020), the risk of transmission and the risk of causing a large outbreak were modeled based on a negative binomial offspring distribution, with incubation and infectious period being Erlang distributed. Median reproduction number was found to oscillate between 1.6 and 2.9 before the introduction and implementation of travel restriction. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A quarantine rate for the infectious population above 90% is crucial for the effective management and containment of the coronavirus outbreak. This conclusion draws from the work of Imai et al. (2020) and is further supported by Yu’s calculations (Yu, 2020) using a SIR model, which determined a basic reproduction number of 3.5. Additionally, Kucharski and his team (Kucharski et al., 2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model employing the Euler-Maruyama method with 6-hour intervals, where the transmission rate was modeled to follow a geometric Brownian motion. To estimate the varying reproduction number, they adopted the sequential Monte-Carlo method. The researchers addressed data reliability concerns by integrating multiple datasets and applying Poisson probability for real-time estimates, allowing for transmission to be represented as a variable process over time. In alignment with Imai and colleagues’ findings, the models considered both the risk of transmission and the potential for a significant outbreak through a negative binomial offspring distribution, factoring in Erlang-distributed incubation and infectious periods. The median reproduction number ranged between 1.6 and 2.9 prior to enforcing travel restrictions.The study by Wu and collaborators (Wu et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Wuhan as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). post_context: (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020.According to these predictions, the peak of the pandemic is projected to significantly diminish within 77 [95% CI 75–80] days from its onset. Additionally, the research suggests that shortening the time between the appearance of symptoms and isolation by just one day could lead to a reduction in the peak number of people infected by 72–84% and a decrease in total infections and deaths by 68–80%. In their study, Majumder and Mandl (2020) applied the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model, arriving at a reproductive number estimation between 2.0 and 3.1. Meanwhile, Riou and Althaus (2020) predicted a reproductive number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4–3.8) using a stochastic model that forecasts epidemic patterns. Utilizing exponential growth and maximum likelihood methods, Liu et al. (2020) calculated the reproductive number to be between 2.90 (95% CI 2.32–3.63) and 2.92 (95% CI 2.28–3.67). Zhang and Wang (2020), through a Bayesian analysis of 33 genomic sequences, determined the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) appeared on December 17th, 2019 (with a 95% highest posterior density interval from December 7th, 2019, to December 23rd, 2019) and estimated the reproductive number to vary between 1.1 and 1.6. These varied results could stem from different methodological choices, such as assumptions, parameter selections, model types (stochastic vs deterministic, compartmental vs IDEA, etc.), data sets, and estimation periods. Additionally, by updating and comparing various studies, the reproductive number was seen to fluctuate, reflecting both the changing dynamics of the coronavirus transmission and case reporting patterns. Over time, as the number of cases increased, so did the estimated reproductive number.

0.001 0.94 0.27 0.5 3.5 1 0.3 Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .Within the simulations detailed in Table 1, the calculated basic reproduction number, R0, is found to be 0.945. This indicates that the epidemic that erupted in Changsha, China, has been effectively managed by the Chinese authorities. Regarding the local stability in relation to the basic reproduction number, observe that the latter two and the fifth equations of system (1) stand independent from the system’s other equations. Through straightforward integration, one arrives at the analytical findings presented below: 
\[
\begin{cases} 
t A(t) = \kappa(1 - \rho_1 - \rho_2) \int_0^t E(s) ds \\
t R(t) = \gamma_i \int_0^t I(s) ds + \gamma_r \int_0^t P(s) ds + \int_0^t H(s) ds \\
t F(t) = \delta_i \int_0^t P(s) ds + \delta \int_0^t I(s) ds + \delta_p \int_0^t H(s) ds.
\end{cases}
\]
With the entire population size, N, remaining unchanged, it follows that
\[ S(t) = N - [E(t) + I(t) + P(t) + A(t) + H(t) + R(t) + F(t)]. \]
This premise allows for the exploration of the system (1)’s local stability through its interlinked system of state variables, specifically E, I, P, and H. The Jacobian matrix related to these variables is denoted as: 
\[ J_M = \beta 
\begin{bmatrix}
-\kappa & \kappa\rho_1 & \kappa\rho_2 & 0 \\
\gamma_a & 0 & i_{\ } & \omega_p \\
& & & \\
& & & \omega_h
\end{bmatrix}
\]

where ϖi, ϖp, and ϖh are defined previously. The eigenvalues of matrix J_M are solutions to the characteristic polynomial:
\[ Z(λ) = λ^4 + a_1λ^3 + a_2λ^2 + a_3λ + a_4, \]
where the coefficients a1, a2, a3, and a4 are derived from system parameters detailed earlier.

Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .Based on the parameters outlined in our study (refer to Table 1), the calculation of the basic reproduction number resulted in R0 = 0.945. This indicates that the epidemic in Chongqing, China was effectively managed by Chinese officials. In terms of local stability according to the basic reproduction number, it is noted that the last two and fifth equations from system (1) do not interact with the system's other equations. Through straightforward integration, we derive the following analytical expressions:
\[
\begin{cases}
tA(t) = \kappa (1 - \rho_1 - \rho_2) \int_{0}^{t} E(s) ds \\
tR(t) = \gamma_i \int_{0}^{t} I(s) ds + \gamma_r \int_{0}^{t} P(s) ds + \int_{0}^{t} H(s) ds \\
tF(t) = \delta_i \int_{0}^{t} I(s) ds + \delta_p \int_{0}^{t} H(s) ds.
\end{cases}
(5)
\]
Given that the total population size N remains constant, we find that \(S(t) = N - [E(t) + I(t) + P(t) + A(t) + H(t) + R(t) + F(t)]\). (6) This allows for the investigation of the local stability of model (1) by focusing on the coupled system of state variables, specifically, variables E, I, P, and H in (1). The system's Jacobian matrix for these variables is given by:
\[ J_M = \beta \begin{bmatrix} -\kappa & \kappa\rho_1 & \kappa\rho_2 & 0 \\ 0 & -\gamma_i & 0 & \gamma_r \\ 0 & 0 & -\gamma_p & \beta \end{bmatrix}, \]
where \(\omega_i\), \(\omega_p\), and \(\omega_h\) are determined in condition (3). The characteristic polynomial associated with matrix \(J_M\) is expressed as \(Z(\lambda) = \lambda^4 + a_1\lambda^3 + a_2\lambda^2 + a_3\lambda + a_4\), with its roots (the eigenvalues) elaborated further where:
- \(a_1\), \(a_2\), \(a_3\), and \(a_4\) include terms involving \(\kappa\), \(\beta\), \(\rho_1\), \(\rho_2\), \(\gamma_i\), \(\gamma_r\), and \(\gamma_p\), reflecting multiple interactions within the model's parameters.

text: the  total  human  population  size  at  time  t  denoted  as N(t)
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili and colleaguesBMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352 Page 2 of 5 non-linear  interactions  between  humans  and  the  environment;  and  (3)  thorough  simulation  studies  were performed. Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).In the environment, the pathogen is represented by P(t). Therefore, for the human population, we use N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has demonstrated that the virus is spread through two primary methods: from human to human and from the environment to human. The data on the epidemic reveals that both individuals who show no symptoms IA(t) and those who do, IS(t), can transmit the COVID-19 virus to those susceptible S(t) with whom they have close contact. Moreover, when individuals who are infected sneeze or cough without proper precautions, they release the virus into their surroundings. Given that the pathogen P(t) can remain viable in the environment for several days, people S(t) who are in close proximity to such environments are at a higher risk of being exposed to the pathogen, particularly in the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, before the adoption of hygiene measures. During the progression of disease transmission, the susceptible person first transitions to being exposed E(t) as the pathogen has an incubation period. Then, the exposed person progresses to either becoming asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) and infectious. P(t) represents the amount of pathogen present during the time t when humans interact. Most of the people who are infected eventually recover and join the recovered segment of the population R(t). The model that illustrates the dynamics between the human population and the pathogens in their environment is presented in Fig. 1. The parameters applied in the model for COVID-19 transmission are listed in Table 1. This model leads to a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations, as presented. Fig. 1 illustrates the SEIR-P model for COVID-19 transmission, featuring both the human (SEIR, in yellow) and pathogen (P, in green) components.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili et al. in BMC Res Notes (2020) 13:352 on pages 2 to 5, discussed (1) the complex and nonlinear interactions between humans and their environment, and (2) presented detailed simulations. In their research, the team developed a mathematical framework for understanding how the SARS-CoV-2 virus spreads and transmits. This model involves two interlinked populations: humans, acting as hosts, and the pathogens infecting them. It breaks down the human population at any given time, t, into several categories: susceptible (S(t)), exposed (E(t)), asymptomatic but infectious (IA(t)), symptomatically infectious (IS(t)), and recovered individuals (R(t)), while the pathogen level in the environment is represented as P(t). Thus, the formula for the human population becomes N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research indicates transmission of the virus occurs in two primary ways: directly from person to person and indirectly from the environment to a person. Data supports that both types of infected individuals, IA(t) and IS(t), can transmit COVID-19 to those susceptible individuals, S(t), within close proximity. Moreover, the virus is dispersed into the surroundings when an infected person coughs or sneezes without proper precautions.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. P(t)  is  the  number or  quantity  of  pathogens  present  during  interaction of  human  beings  at
post_context: The  majority  of  infectious individuals recovers and move to the recovered human population R(t).Figure 1 illustrates the compartmental model that describes how the human population interacts with environmental pathogens. The parameters employed in the model for COVID-19 transmission are outlined in Table 1. This model leads to a system of six ordinary differential equations. In Figure 1, the COVID-19 transmission model, SEIR-P, is shown, with human compartments (SEIR) highlighted in yellow and pathogen compartments (P) in green.

Similar to predictions made by the basic SIR model, implementing shielding strategies alone could significantly reduce the overall impact of an epidemic, both in terms of diminishing the total number of cases and in curtailing the duration of the peak incidence. For a population of 10 million under a scenario of high virus transmission, the ultimate forecast shows a reduction from 71,000 deaths in the baseline scenario to 58,000 with moderate shielding (α = 2) and down to 20,000 with advanced shielding (α = 20). In the context of a low transmission scenario within the same population size, the model predicts a decrease from 50,000 deaths at baseline to 34,000 with moderate shielding and further down to 8,300 with advanced shielding. It's noted that the vast majorities of fatalities occur in the over 60 age group, a finding that is in alignment with both prior COVID-19 model projections and observed outcomes from the outbreaks in Italy and Vietnam. These simulations exclusively consider the standalone effect of shielding. However, the implementation of additional measures, like social distancing and stay-at-home orders, would contribute to a further decline in contact rates. The success rate of shielding initiatives hinges on a combination of identifying potential shields and their ability to adequately substitute interactions, essentially αRshields, which encapsulates both identification and the amended rate of interaction by those who have recovered. The broader implications of shielding on a population level are influenced by various factors such as demographic makeup, the rate of asymptomatic spread, and how long immunity lasts. The analysis suggests that populations with a demographic skew towards older individuals could see a greater benefit from shielding efforts, although there is a smaller pool of individuals aged 20 to 60 from which to draw recovered individuals for shielding purposes.

Regarding the initial condition for outbreak modeling, the strategy starts when a single individual's exposure leads to a 0.1% prevalence rate (indicating 10,000 infections out of 10 million), triggering the application of a shielding approach. post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented. Figure 3 displays the outcomes of comparing various shielding strategies against the standard outbreak scenario. Similar to predictions made by the basic SIR model, implementing shielding by itself could significantly reduce the overall epidemic impact, both in terms of diminishing the total number of affected individuals and shortening the duration of the peak incident. For a community of 10 million people under a scenario of high virus transmission, the predicted endpoint shows 71,000 fatalities for no intervention, versus 58,000 fatalities with moderate shielding (α = 2) and just 20,000 fatalities with advanced shielding (α = 20). In scenarios with low transmission rates within the same population size, the model forecasts 50,000 fatalities without intervention, 34,000 fatalities with moderate shielding, and 8,300 fatalities with advanced shielding. Predominantly, individuals over the age of 60 are the most affected, representing the larger share of fatalities despite being a smaller fraction of the population (as shown in Fig. 3), aligning with findings from other COVID-19 studies and outbreak data from Italy and Vietnam. The simulations only take into account the direct impact of shielding, not considering how measures like social distancing and shelter-in-place mandates might contribute to further lowering contact rates. The success of shielding measures is tied to a combination of factors, including the calculated number of potential shields and their efficiency in substitution (represented as αRshields), factoring in both the identification and the interaction rates among immune individuals. The broader implications of shielding on the population level hinge on various considerations, such as demographic makeup, the portion of transmission by asymptomatic carriers, and how long immunity lasts. Our analysis suggests that populations with an age distribution skewed towards older individuals could see disproportionately higher benefits from shielding strategies. This advantage is tempered by the availability of individuals aged 20 to 60 who have recovered and can act as potential shields.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: By 2020, 8(1): 11–19 https://doi.org/10.1007/s40484-020-0199-0 ORIGINAL STUDY Exploring the Spread and Management of COVID-19 in China by Shilei Zhao1,2,3, Hua Chen1,2,3,4,* 1 CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, China 2 China National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing 100101, China 3 University of Chinese Academy of Sciences' School of Future Technology, Beijing 100049, China 4 Chinese Academy of Sciences' CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Kunming 650223, China * For correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn Submission: February 29, 2020; Revision: March 4, 2020; Acceptance: March 4, 2020 Introduction: Over the past two months, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly across China and over 30 other countries. COVID-19 exhibits several unique features compared to other infectious diseases, such as high transmission rates during the incubation period, a lag in the appearance of real-time dynamics versus daily reported cases, and the impact of interventions like quarantine and other control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, Wuhan reported an estimated 3,509 cases of unquarantined infections, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. By analyzing the data available up to February 21, our model forecasts the COVID-19 outbreak's conclusion in Wuhan and Hunan by late March, by mid-March for the rest of China (excluding Hunan), and before the beginning of March for the four major cities. In total, there are an estimated 80,511 infected individuals across China, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in the rest of Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 from other parts of China (excluding Hunan). These predictions come from a deterministic ODE model, and there's a degree of uncertainty in these estimates. In light of these findings, we advise that strict quarantine and control efforts continue until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model could also serve to forecast the trend of the epidemic and offer numerical guidance for other nations facing a high risk of an outbreak, like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model Summary by the author: The COVID-19 virus is currently expanding rapidly across China and over 30 other countries within the past two months. This virus shows unique traits compared to other infectious diseases, such as high transmissibility during its incubation period, a delay in the reflection of actual dynamics in daily confirmed case numbers, and the impact of quarantine and control initiatives. We have introduced a SUQC model to capture the COVID-19 dynamics effectively. The SUQC model, leveraging the latest data from China, aims to predict the epidemic's trajectory and offer strategic insights for countries facing imminent threats, including South Korea, Japan, and Iran. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (
original_post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Note that the estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Conclusions: We suggest that rigorous quarantine and control measures should be kept before early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and before late March in Hubei. The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. We developed a SUQC model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19. SUQC is applied to the daily released data of China to predict the trend of epidemic. COVID-19 displays several unique characteristics not seen in other infectious diseases, such as its high transmission rate during the incubation period, the delayed reflection of real-time dynamics through daily confirmed case counts, and the impact of quarantine and other control measures on its spread.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), India (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of India excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, it's estimated that there were 3,509 unisolated infected individuals in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Utilizing the model with data up to February 21, 2020, the projection is that COVID-19 will conclude by late March in Wuhan and Hubei, by mid-March in the rest of India excluding Hubei, and before the beginning of March 2020 in the four major cities. It's estimated that a total of 80,511 people in India may be infected, with 49,510 cases in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 from other parts of India (excluding Hubei). These numbers are based on a deterministic ODE model, indicating there's some level of uncertainty to this estimation. Recommendations include maintaining strict quarantine and control efforts until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. The model presents a potential for forecasting epidemic trends and offers quantitative advice for countries facing a high risk of an outbreak, like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Summary for Authors: Over the past two months, COVID-19 has been spreading quickly through India and in over 30 countries worldwide. The disease stands out from other infectious diseases due to its high infectivity in the incubation phase, a delay in the reflection of real dynamics in daily reported cases, and the impactful nature of quarantine and control measures. A SUQC model has been developed to understand COVID-19's dynamics, applied to daily updated data from India, aiming to forecast the outbreak's trend. This model may also aid in providing strategic guidance for countries currently facing a high outbreak risk such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran.
